content:
Pre-falling angels are considering the decision of falling and considering taking their first steps in that direction. They're being introduced to angels of darkness—the fallen angels who are devoted entirely to darkness and who have turned completely away from God—and the falling angels who are partially working for God and partially working for darkness on their own terms—and the pre-falling angels are being tempted.

The pre-falling angels haven't defied or betrayed God yet, not even partially. But they're intrigued and they're listening to what angels of darkness are preaching. They're listening to the noise, which is what people do nonstop when they betray people.

Angelic discernment is different from human discernment. An angel deciding whether to take that step in the direction of a fallen angel and start the process of falling is a different form of discernment from a human practicing discernment when trying something or believing something. Angelic discernment comes with a massive price, meaning once the mistake is made, there is never any turning back. When a human being makes a mistake in their discernment process, there's always redemption. There's always the ability to change path and course despite what the mistakes have been and how grave they are. A human being can make a grave mistake and completely fail with using discernment and still fight to rebirth and reclaim and evolve from a mistake, unlike angels.

children.content: Annette Smith where?
Annette Smith No it doesn't.

Loretta Zortman 

Revelation 12:7–9 — The Fall of Satan and His Angels
“Then war broke out in heaven. Michael and his angels fought against the dragon, and the dragon and his angels fought back. But he was not strong enough, and they lost their place in heaven.
The great dragon was hurled down—that ancient serpent called the devil, or Satan, who leads the whole world astray. He was hurled to the earth, and his angels with him.”

Interpretation:
This passage clearly refers to Satan and his rebellious angels being cast out of heaven after a spiritual battle. It’s the most direct reference to fallen angels in Scr

Isaiah 14:12–15 — Lucifer’s Fall (Symbolic)
“How you are fallen from heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning!
How you are cut down to the ground, you who weakened the nations!”

Interpretation:
Though this is a taunt against the king of Babylon, many theologians interpret it as a dual prophecy referring to Satan’s pride and fall. The name Lucifer (Latin for “light-bringer”) is often associated with the fallen angel.

Ezekiel 28:12–17 — Lament over the King of Tyre (Symbolic of Satan)
“You were the anointed guardian cherub. I placed you; you were on the holy mountain of God…
Your heart was proud because of your beauty; you corrupted your wisdom for the sake of your splendor. I cast you to the ground…”

Interpretation:
This is often viewed as a symbolic description of Satan’s original position and prideful fall, couched in the lament for a human king.

Jude 1:6 — Angels Who Abandoned Their Position
“And the angels who did not keep their positions of authority but abandoned their proper dwelling—these he has kept in darkness, bound with everlasting chains for judgment on the great Day.”

Interpretation:
This refers to angels who rebelled—possibly linked to the Genesis 6 account (see below)—and are now awaiting judgment

2 Peter 2:4
“For if God did not spare angels when they sinned, but sent them to hell, putting them in chains of darkness to be held for judgment

Interpretation:
Clearly speaks of angels who sinned and are being restrained until the final judgment.

Genesis 6:1–4 — The “Sons of God”

“The sons of God saw that the daughters of humans were beautiful, and they married any of them they chose…”

Interpretation:
Some traditions (especially in Jewish and early Christian texts like 1 Enoch) interpret “sons of God” as angels who left heaven, sinned with human women, and were punished. This is controversial and debated among scholars.

Job 1:6–12 and Job 2:1–7 — Satan Among the Sons of God

“One day the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came with them…”

Interpretation:
Shows Satan as a distinct being among heavenly beings—likely fallen, yet still granted access to God’s presence to test Job.
